index.html.title: index
index.html.description:
History course by Marcel Röthlisberger, Gymnasium Lerbermatt, Switzerland. This website is for internal use at Gymnasium in classes held by Marcel Röthlisberger. Sources are provided. No copyright infringement is intended.Everything that is now, is something that has become. Freely after André Holenstein: «Das Seiende als etwas Gewordenes verstehen» This course runs over the 4 years of Gymnasium and provides a chronological overview of mostly Western aspects, with an open mind to international, non-European aspects, especially colonialism and decolonisation. We are Europeans based in Europe. An understanding of European culture, politics, History, society, languages and customs is essential for students who live and mature here. It is equally important, though, for all Europeans, to have a deep understanding of the interconnectedness of Europe and Europeans with the Earth and European societies’ responsibility for their actions in the past and their consequences. Our students are on the brink of becoming fully entitled members of our democratic society. They shall have the tools to understand dependencies, meaning of text and speech, culture and customs, political processes and possibilities. Not least, they shall understand that change is possible, necessary, and inevitable.“The past is a foreign country; they do things differently there.” LP Hartley, The Go-Between By looking at the other, people become aware of the self. A deeper understanding of other possibilities of living a human’s life is essential. The humanities – History among them, but also literature and cultural studies – offer tools and insight into other people’s minds and living conditions. Spielvogel chapters (restricted access from within the school)Text sources under public domain:
Christopher Brooks, Western Civilization: A Concise History, Volume 1
Christopher Brooks, Western Civilization: A Concise History, Volume 2
Christopher Brooks, Western Civilization: A Concise History, Volume 3Marcel Röthlisberger Gymnasium Lerbermatt ©MMXXV

100-year1/104-ancient-greece/104-i-ancie.title: 104-I - Ancient Greece – Overview
100-year1/104-ancient-greece/104-i-ancie.description:
Overview text Take notes of the most important aspects mentioned in the text. Why is Greek culture still relevant today? Alphabet ɑ, β, ... Alphabeta → alphabet Phoenician alphabet The letters of the Phoenician alphabet, the earliest alphabetic system (end of 2nd millenium BC). Variations of this system spread into all kinds of regions and these simpler scripts were more widely used, if by an elite minority, though.
First letter: Alpha, coming from “Aleph” (West Semitic word for “ox”) The Greeks, who called themselves Hellenes from the 8th century onwards, did not form a homogenous political nation. They consisted of several tribes and independent city-states (poleis, singular: polis). Nonetheless, the Greeks had a shared identity. They talked the same language, albeit in different dialects, and used the same alphabet inherited from the Phoenicians, a tradespeople from the eastern Mediterranean.Apart from that, the Greeks were unified by their religious beliefs. Greek religion was polytheistic, i.e., there were several gods. Although they were immortal and enjoyed eternal youth, they had strong human features and acted like mortals. According to the Greek belief system, the gods lived on Mount Olympus, the highest mountain in Greece, as a family. Their leaders were Zeus and his wife Hera. The Olympian gods (see Pantheon, below), all relatives of them, had different fields of duties: Apollo (healing, fortune-telling, poetry), Aphrodi­te (love), Artemis (hunt), Ares (war), Poseidon (the sea), Hermes (messenger of the gods, god of the travellers, merchants and thieves). In order to get the god’s help, they had to be appeased with sacrifices. These adoration ceremonies took place outside the temples. Some sanctuaries became very famous. In Olympia, Greeks from various states met since 776 BC to compete in sports in honour of Zeus. In Delphi, the Greeks consulted with the oracle of Apollo and also took part in games in his honour.Antique Pantheon
Art on pottery Runners, c. 500 BC, Louvre One of the characteristics of the visual arts was their uniformity throughout the numerous city-states. Until Hellenistic times, it was mostly communities who ordered pieces of art, so they were basically made for the public and for religious purposes (e.g. the Acropolis). Along vase painters, sculptors were very skilful. In classical times they managed to create vivid, lively sculptures which they integrated into buildings (temples, effigies, palaces). The first sculptural portraits were also made by Greek sculptors.The literary and artistic achievements of the Greeks were a major influence for occidental culture. The two epics of the destruction of Troy (Iliad) and Ulysses’ Odyssey by Homer determined the Greeks’ picture of their gods and historical origins. Myths and sagas initially formed the major parts of Greek historiography, too. Then, Herodot (~485 until after 430) and Thukydides (~460 until ~400) introduced a new way of historical thinking. Both historians were keen on writing truthfully about contemporary events and on showing the roots of important events. Tragedy and comedy developed out of cultic performances in honour of the gods.Initially, Greek philosophers were learned, wise men (e.g. Pythagoras, Thales), who tried to explain the world on a rational basis using different disciplines (e.g. ethics, mathematics, physics, music, poetry). Socrates (469 – 399) opposed the sophists, for whom man was the measure of all things. He looked for a base of the universe which was objective, outside human influence. He also looked for standards for human knowledge and for moral conducts. Plato (427 – 347) wrote Socrates’ teachings down in the form of dialogues. He himself thought about the ideal political state, which ought to be in harmony with human nature and the immortality of the human soul. Plato assumed that besides the ever-changing world, there are unchangeable archetypes (original forms) of all things, which man can only grasp through his thinking: ideas. Plato’s most influential student was Aristotle (384 – 322). He collected the whole knowledge of his time, and, by putting it into a clear, disctinct order, developed significant criteria for scientific work.(Adapted from Grundwissen Geschichte, tr. Rö.)Timeline ~ 2000 to ~1000 Indo-European tribes advance onto the Attic peninsula from the North: The Proto-Greeks ~2000 to ~1400 Minoan culture on Crete, first European High Culture ~1600 to ~1000 Mycenaean time ~1200 to ~1000 Decay of Mycenaean palace culture, “Dorian invasion” ~1000 to ~750 “Dark Ages” Rise of a great number of city-states (poleis) 776 First Olympic Games ~750 to ~550 Greek colonisation ~594 Reforms of Solon in Athens. Aristocracy weakened, peasants strengthened 509 – 507 Beginning of democracy in Athens 500 – 479 Persian Wars 477 Delian League 431 – 404 Peloponnesian War 336 – 323 Alexander the Great (* 356) rules over Greece and conquers his empire 323 † Alexander. Empires of the Diadochi (followers). Fast decline and disintegration of Alexander’s empire 146 Greece becomes Roman Province 30 BC Egypt becomes Roman Province. With that, also the last successor state of Alexander’s empire ends

100-year1/104-ancient-greece/104-ii-deve.title: 104-II - Development of Greek Culture
100-year1/104-ancient-greece/104-ii-deve.description:
From Evidence to Outlines of Societies or: How can what we have found help us reconstruct what was? Deduct From the pictures given here, what can be learned about the Minoans? Discuss, speculate, exchange (no extra research necessary). THEN find the blue box at the end of this subchapter. Minoan Crete, map on wikimedia.commons, showing sites of the Minoan culture, c. 3100 – c. 1100 BC
Reconstruction of the palace of Knossos
Bull-leaping fresco from the palace of Knossos. Heavily reconstructed. The original parts are the elevated fragments.
Dolphin fresco from the palace of Knossos
Bull head rhyton (cup)
Bull-leaper figurine, 1600BC-1450BC
The Phaistos Disk, side A. 2nd millenium BC. Undeciphered script.
Figures from the Agia Triada Sarcophagus, c. 1400 BCMinoans, what we know on Crete Europe’s first cities palace culture (Knossos) Seafaring nation, traders, rich and peaceful → no fortifications around palaces (Crete isolated), no warrior class; probably high status of women script (undeciphered: from the Phaistos Disk, Linear A. readable: Linear B)
more information on World History Encyclopedia
Minoan Culture ending
Location of the study area and the Eastern Mediterranean geotectonic setting. (a) Red line isopach (in cm) of the ash layer (2); letter T in black circle: putative tsunami deposits. (b) Black dots, main centres of the Minoan Crete; White dots, Cretan sites mentioned: 1. Amnisos; 2. Gouves; 3. Palaikastro; 4. Pirgos; Black triangle, main summits, altitude in meters. Edited in Adobe Illustrator CS6 2020 version 16.0. source Thera, today: Santorini, situated 110 km north of Greece. Volcanic eruption in ~1600 BC. Find out Similarities and differences to Minoan culture

Reconstruction of Mycenae
Lion Gate, entrance to the palace of Mycenae
“Mask of Agamemnon”, gold, middle 16th century BC.Myth and archaeology Heinrich Schliemann, who discovered Mycenae in the 19th century, found what he wanted to find: “proof” that the Homeric epics (the Illiad and the Odyssey) were based on historic facts. So, when he found the gold mask shown above, he felt the strong need to connect it to the mythological king Agamemnon, without even knowing when it was made, let alone who it really depicted.
Linear B script
Mycenean vase, 1400-1400 BCEvidence of a collapse What we know: palaces were left new Greek dialects were established ~ 1200: Mycenaean palace culture collapses But why? “Dorian Invasion” (?) natural catastrophes and wars inner problems of the system …
Displacement of Greek Dialects at the End of the Bronze Age.
Greek Dialects c. 800 BC

headers.heading: First "Civilisation" in European space: the Minoans

100-year1/104-ancient-greece/104-iii-dar.title: 104-III - Dark Age → Polis
100-year1/104-ancient-greece/104-iii-dar.description:
Research task Find out why they are called the Dark Ages. What conditions led to the establishment of city-states (poleis)? How and why did Greek colonisation take place, and what were the consequences? Greek landscape Look at this map of Greece: describe the landscape! Where do you see difficulties in transport and communication? Chris Butler, adapted by RöM

Polis in the landscape Multi column A Greek city-state, consisting of an urban settlement as centre its hinterland used for agriculture its inhabitants a polis is politically autonomous in economical autarchy able to defend its citizens and territory
Greek Colonisation 750 – 550 BC. Fast population growth, crop failures and a hereditary system in which the estate of the father is being parted among the sons, along with the search for new trade places lead to Greek colonisation. It was organized by the home cities, sometimes even forced on certain parts of the population. The consequences were a flourish of trade and economy. Apart from that, Greek language and culture were spread across major parts of the Mediterranean. (Duden Basiswissen Geschichte)

headers.heading: Dark Age Greece and the Rise of the Polis (c. 1100–750 BC).

100-year1/104-ancient-greece/104-iv-art-.description:
Periods of Greek History Archaic (750-500) Classical (500-323) Hellenistic (336-30 BC) → criterion: art Sculpture
Statue of a Kouros, youth, c. 600 BC. ☞ The figure stands in contrapposto: one leg is engaged, the other one free | Source
so-called Peplos Kore, a statue of a maiden, ca. 530 BC | Source
Reconstruction of the paint on the Peplos Kore from remains found on the original | Source
Pottery
Amphora (large two-handled vase) signed by Exekias with Achilles and Ajax playing draughts, Archaic Period, c. 550-525 BC. | Source
Terracotta neck-amphora (jar) with lid and knob, Attributed to Exekias. Archaic, ca. 540 B.C., Terracotta; black-figure | Source
Sculpture
Sculpture showing either Zeus or Poseidon | Source
Early Classical or “severe” style statue of Apollo originally placed in the west pediment of the Apollo temple in Olympia, ca. 460 BC | Source
Architecture (example: Akropolis, Athens)
Akropolis of Athens | Source
Caryatids at the Erechteion, Akropolis, Athens | Source
The Parthenon, the temple of Pallas Athena Parthenos | Source
Original statues from the pediment of the Parthenon, now on display at the British museum. They have been called the “Elgin marbles”, after Lord Elgin, who brought them to London in the 19th century. | Source
A reconstruction of how the Acropolis may have looked in ancient times, including the Parthenon. Illustration by Kate Morton. | Source
Pottery
Terracotta red-figure volute-krater (mixing bowl for wine and water) from the late classical period (ca. 330-210 BC), Greek, South-Italian, Apulian | Source
Relief
Marble relief with a dancing maenad. Adaptation of work attributed to Kallimachos. Early Imperial, Augustan, ca. 27 B.C. – A.D. 14 | Source
Architecture: Theater
Before a modern-day performance in the Theatre of Epidauros | Source
Source
Olympia
Race track, “stadium” in Olympia | Source Reconstruction of the complex of Olympia
Delphi
Apollo temple in Delphi | Source
Themis in the role of the Pythia prophecies a son to Aigeus. Attic red-figure kylix, 440–430 BC. From Vulci. | Source
Heinrich Leutemann, Das Orakel von Delphi, 19th century | Source “Priestess of Delphi”, John Collier, 1891 Famous oracle predictions from Delphi: Oedipus: you will kill your father and marry your mother. Not knowing he was adopted he left his beloved foster parents, only to bump into his real father (whom he killed) and marry a queen who happened to be his mother.
Croesus: “if you cross the river, a great empire will be destroyed.” (more or less) → he thought of the Persian one, but it was his own.
John Collier, Priestess of Delphi, 1891, oil on canvas | Source

100-year1/104-ancient-greece/104-vi-s-ci.title: 104-VI-S - Cities and Citizens
100-year1/104-ancient-greece/104-vi-s-ci.description: Negotiate with your partner(s): What is a city? What is a citizen? Read Aristotle (384-322) on citizenship How does Aristotle define citizens? How does he define city? What do we learn about social classes in an ancient Greek polis (Athens)? Who had political rights, who didn’t?

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
